div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7207] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: OVERTURES AT WASHINGTON.
PROSPECTS HOPEFUL.
div.p: -The Italian Ambassador, after a prolonged conference with Count (Jassini on Saturday, conferred with President Roosevelt. The Japanese Minister Takashira was then summoned to, New York and had a* prolonged interview with President Roosevelt in the evening. M. Takahira afterwards stated that no progress could be made until communication had been received from St. Petersburg. (R. )
London, June, 5.

According to the “Standard, ” it is the opinion the American Ambassador at St. Petersburg that it is not likely that the above, mentioned communications will be made for a fortnight, until the excitement has subsided, but it is his personal opinion that the prospects are hopeful. {Reuter. )

div.head: RUSSIAN SQUADRON SIGHTED.
div.p: Hong Kong, June 5.
One ship of the Russian volunteer squadron, 2 torpedo-boats, one cruiser, and several trans- ports have been sighted 240 miles south-eastwards of here. ( Reuter. )

div.head: DISARMING SHIPS AT MANILA.
div.p: Manila, June 5.

div.head: DISARMING SHIPS AT MANILA
div.p: Admiral Enquist asked permission to repair here, The American authorities report that the ‘ Oleg” will require 60 days, the “Aurora” 30, and the “Jemtchug’ 7. Admiral Enquist says ' that he left the scene of battle on Saturday night and did not know that it continued on Sunday. (Reuter,)
Washington, June 5.
The United States have ordered the immediate disarming of the Russian warships at Manila. (Reuter. )

div.head: APPOINTMENT FOR GEN. TREPOFF.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 5.

General Trepoff has been appointed assistant Minister of the interior and head of the Police and Gendarmerie with extensive powers throughout the Empire. He retains the Governor Generalship of St. Petersburg. {Reuter. )

div.head: IMPORTANT RUSSIAN ! RESIGNATIONS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 5.
Admiral Alexoieff has resigned the Vice-royalty of the Far East, and M. Bulyguin his appointment as Minister of the Interior. The resignations have not been accepted. (Reuter, j

div.head: THE ANGLO-JAPANESE ALLIENCE A “TIMES” ARTICLE.
div.p: The “Times, ” in a leading article, remarks that the importance ot Lord Lansdowne’s statement regarding the alliance with Japan is heightened by Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman s subsequent declaration that any Liberal Government would follow faithfully and zealously Lord Lansdowne’s policy. The 'Times” proceeds that we are confident that there can be no stronger bulwark for the future maintenance of peace in Asia than a solid alliance between Great Britain and Japan for mutually defensive support. The moment is ripe for suck a step. (Reuter. )

div.head: CHANNEL FLEET IN A FOG TWO COLLISIONS.
div.p: On Saturday night, as the Channel Fleet was steaming here, it was enveloped in a dense fog near Dover, owing to which the battleship “Ciesar” collided with the S. S. “Afghanistan, which sank and 18 persons were drowned. The battleship “Triumph” also collided with the battleship “Swiftsure” and the latter was badly damaged. The “Ciesar” and ‘Triumph” are both slightly damaged. (Reuter. )

div.head: KING ALFONSO IN LONDON. RECEIVED BY PRINCE OF WALES.
div.p: King Alfonso has left here for London. (It. )

King Alfonso, escorted by the warships, reached Portsmouth at noon and was received by the Prince of Wales, who accompanied him to London. It rained incessantly but a large crowd welcomed the King on his arrival, Extraordinary police precautions were taken to ensure his safety. (Reuter. )

div.head: M. LOU BET TO VISIT MADRID.
div.p: President Loubet has accepted the invitation of King Alfonso to visit Madrid in the autumn. (Reuter.;
M. Loubet will visit King Alfonso at Madrid in October next.
Chamber of Deputies. —M. Doumer stigmatised the attempt on the King of Spain’* life. His words were greeted with load applause. (Havat. t

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Hampshire beat Worcestershire. Captain Greig scored two centuries. (Reuter. )

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Cairo Water Company has commenced to work the pumps of the artesian wells at Rod el-Farag.
H. M. S. “Juno, " which convoyed the Admiralty dredger “St Lawrence” from Malta to Alexandria, left our harbour again early this morning.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Mousky district of Cairo during to morrow night and at daylight on Thursday will be poisoned by the police.
OuR Stamboul contemporaries publish a new list of subscriptions towards the Hedjaz Railway Fund, bringing up the general total to Piastres Turkish 82,848, 550.
San Stefano Casino. — The management of the Casino inform us that a grand concert will be given there on Sunday next at 10 a. m., when the orchestra will be composed of 50 musicians.
Suez Canal. —On the 1st and 2nd inst 17 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these 11 were British, 1 French, 3 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Norwegian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 485, 144. 28.

Police Bribery. —A court martial will be held at the Alexandria Gouvemorat to-day to try a policeman for having taken a bribe to the amount of P. T. 5 from a bicyclist, who was riding without a light after dark.

Lands at Ghizeh. —The Ministry of Public Works has ordered two powerful pumping installations from Europe. They will be used to convert some lands to the east of Gbizeh into sefi irrigation and will be set up at the mouth of El Khachab canal.

Our Confreres. —M. Charles Camel, manager of the “Journal du Cairo, ’ is going to Europe on leave to-morrow by the Austrian boat. M. G. Vayssie, general manager of the Havas Agency and editor of the “Journal da Cairo, ” is leaving on the 16th inst by the Messageries steamer.

The North German Lloyd’s steamers to Naples and Marseilles are nearly full up for the forthcoming departures. In tact, all the cabins for the sailing of- 14th June are booked. The next departure after that of the 14th inst. will be on July 5, and many applications have already been received for berths by that boat, so it will be necessary for persons intend-ing to leave by that steamer to book at once.

The Union Artistique Francaise is giving a dramatic performance, followed by a ball, on Saturday next at the new Casino de la Con-ronne, Ibrahimieh. The programme includes the well-known comedy, L’ete de la Saint• Martin, a humorous conference entitled La Femme, and a one-act farce, Lee Boulingrins, The performance will commence at 9. 15 and at 11. 30 dancing will be engaged in. The union is to be congratulated on its new locale.

Alfonso XIII. at Paris. —The young King of Spain, who has just made such a stir in Paris, is a very enlightened and highly intel? ligent young man. Many Berlitz pupils will, no doubt, hi delighted to know that he was at one time their fellow student, having learned English by the celebrated system of teaching to which Mr. Berlitz has given his name. The Berlite schools have thus been royally honored, after having won public favor throughout the entire world. [Advt. ].

A Descendant of Mohamh). —The death is announced of the Newab Begum of Murshi-dabad, at the age of 71. She was the widow of the late Sir Syed Ali Khan, G. C. I. E., Newab Bahadur of Murshidabad. There were several children of the marriage, but only two daughters survive. Prince Syed, the heir, died in 1803. The Begum was a descendant of the Prophet Mohamed, and was remarkable for her charities and her interest in the education of women. At the Diamond Jubilee she was decorated with the Imperial Order of the Crown of India.

The Priestess of Osiris.—Archteologists in Paris will in a few days be in a position to view the whole of the rich Egyptological collections recovered by M. Gayet daring his excavations among the huge cemeteries of ancient Antinoe. Besides the tomb of Khelmis, the magical dancer, and the victors in the Olympic games, a new monument of the highest interest has been received. It is that of Glethias, “the clothier of the images of Osiris of Antinoe.0 All the crowns, garlands, thvrses of flowers, as well as the objects used by the priestess in perfuming and adorning the statue, have been recovered.

LA Revue International^! d’Egypte, of which the second number/ has just been issued, has evidently oomofo stay, which is a matter of congratulation, for it fills what was a decided want yd the literature of the country. The presents' number is quite as interesting as its predecessor, and contains among other thing* seasonable articles on “Lea Habitations Economiquea et les Cit* Jrtrdins en Egypte,’ by M. F. Bourgeois ; ‘ I* Tuberculose en Esrypte,” by Dr. Vallaso poulo'; “La constitution et la fertility de U terfe arable d’aprfcs les recherches raentes,” by M. Victor Mosseri ; “Richard Wagner ei Mathilde Wesendonck,” by M. V. Nourisson, etc., including the translation of a timelj article on the present crisis at the A1 Azbai University from the pen of a ulema. Altogether, a decidedly interesting publication.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE IN VIENNA. RECEIVED BY THE EMPEROR.
div.p: The Khedive has bad an audience of the Emperor Francis Joseph. (Reuter.)
H.H. the Khedive has paid a visit to the Emperor. (Havas.}

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
div.p: Our Medinet el-Fayoum Correspondent writes : — The cotton /worm has appeared in the villages of Agcr^in and Nazleh. Some of the worms have been tent to Cairo to be examined. Mr. Kuppell arrival at the Fayoum on Saturday and left for Nazleh to aid in fighting against tho worm. Our Minet el Kamii Correspontot state* that the following are tho villages of Minet el Kivmh Markaz in which the cotton worm has appeared :—El Magazer, Kafr El Sohby, Kafr el Walaga, El Bakkashin, Kafr Abd-Allal* Shoufas, and El Shokr.

div.head: THE GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY!
div.p: This company, which is the first of those to be formed under the programme of the Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company, as to the character and scope of which we recently gave our readers particulars, was registered at the Mixed Tribunals on the lgth ultimo. It has been formed with the object of takingNiyer from the parent company an area of 9,000 feddans of laud situated on the west bank of the Nile and extending northwards from Ras el Khahg. As this property stands at present it may be divided into four parts according to its condition, as fully cultivated, partly cultivated, fallow, and wastes Of the fuLy cultivated land there are 2,100 feddans, which it is expected will in 1906 yield an income of about £4,500. Although the remaining 7,000 feddans consist of three different qualities of land, in estimating the probable return to be had from them it has been wisely determined to regard the whole as conbktiug of land reqairing reclamation. The prospects thus obtained are therefore bated upon a very moderate estimate of the probabie returns and will almost certainly be exceeded in the aotual working. Prior to the purchase of this property, Sir William Willcocks caretuUy examined an4 reported most favorably upon a large tract of Government waste laud adjoiuing it which the company desire^to acquire. The purchase of this is, however,\in abeyance owing to the decision of the Government not to sell any large parcel of its lands at present The capital of the company has been fixed at £400,000, the whole of which has been subscribed, and it is anticipated that in 1913 the company will have realised from sales and revenues large profits and will be in a position to pay a dividend exoeeding 10% from the ►,000 feddans that will then remain in its possession. As we have indicated, the probable profits have been purposely estimated below the figures that might have been assumed if the company had been actuated by no other desir* than that of presenting its prospects in the most favorable light, but the course followed by the company is one deserving of the hight est commendation and one that cannot fail to add largely to the interest that will certainly be taken in its future.

div.head: SUDAN SLAVE TRADE.
div.p: Captain McMurdo, the director of the Rer prassion of Slave Trade Department, is now making a tour of inspection in the Sobat region and the Upper Nile districts, in order to satisfy himself as to the measures that are being takeu in those parts of the Sudan for hindering the traffic in slaves. There can be no doubt that the slave trade, though it has as yet by no means been stamped out, has received a very great check in the Sudan. The people have learned to respect, and also to dread, the slavery laws. Seventeen persons were convicted of dealing in slaves during the course of the past year. Of these, one (Ibrahim Wad Mah-moud; was sentenced to death for murder and rebellion. The remaining sixteen were condemned to various terms of imprisonment. The fear which the application of the law has* inspired produces, without doubt, a salutary effeot on the whole, bat it sometimes leads to sad consequences. As regards Sudanese domestic slavery, as distinguished from the slavtf trade, as much progress as could reasonably be expected is being made in eradicating this institution from the country. By carefully protecting the interests of those who were previously slaves, and it the same time gradually employing them on remunerative work in other capacities— should they be unwilling to return to their masters as ordinary servants—the authorities will eventually,with the concurrence and assistance of the inhabitants themselves, gradually transform the status of slavery, and substitute for it a system of paid labour, whioh will probably bo acceptable to master and servant alike. Captain McMurdo's inspection in the south-t3rn Sudan will lead to the control of the slave traffic in those far off regions. The slave raiding cases, which occur in that part of the Sudan, appear to be more in the way of reprisals arising from tribal quarrels than for purposes of export. When the machinery of the Slave Trade Repression Department throughout the Sudan is satisfactorily organised, slavery will have reoeived its death-blow,

div.head: NILE NAVIGATION,
TONNAGE CERTIFICATES. SERIOUS Charges
div.p: “Nothing is more encouraging to the fiscal reformer,” says Lord Cromer in dealing with the subject of Nile Navigation in his last Report, “than to observe the manner in which the country responds to any measures taken, in the direction of the relief of fiscal burthens.” The allusion is to the extraordinarily large increase which has taken plaoe in the boat traffio on the Nile since the look tolls were removed. The traffio is growing enormously, but the figures are not available, save in one case—that of the locks at the Delta Barrage. In 1845^15,867 boats passed through this look. At the close of 1900, the tolls were removed. In 1903, no less than 35,732 boats passed through the look. In 1904, the number increased to 41,740. At the Kasr-el-Nil bridge at Cairo, the officials in charge have given op trying to oount the boats. They pass through in such a rush and in suoh dose order, that it is impossible to oount them. These facts and figures, imperfeot though they be, are sufficient to show that there has been an enormous increase in the river traffic. It will almost certainly develop still further, now t^hat the lioense fees on boats have been removed It is, however, to be anticipated that every year steam-bargcs—of which there are already a considerable number—will take the place of sailing-boats. We regret to state, however, that there is a great deal of abuse in oonneotion with the tonnage measurements and a wide-spread system of fraud is in vogue. A Cairo correspondent gives the following examples of the abuse. We quota his letter in fall “In connection with the recent interest taken in matters of navigation on the Nile, 1 wish to draw attention to a long-standing abuse whioh it is high time shoald be stopped. I refer to the tonnage measurement of native boats, for which, as you maybe aware, certificates are issued by the Government, in the form of receipts for the navigation dues. In selling or purchasing produce, etc., or chartering boats, it is the custom to use these reoeipts very often as the basis of the transaction, which is a oonvenienoe and economises time and trouble. Now comes in the abuse. I have myself seen i^the hands of boatmen, two different certificates for the same boat, showing a very considerable difference in the tonnage. The second one, which is as much as fifty or a hundred ardebs less than the actual measurement, is of course used in purchasing, and the other in selling or chartering. The false one is of oourse obtained by the use of the inevitable nimble dollar, but considering the amounts involved I think it is high time a refonn ii made. I would therefore, whilst apologising for occupying your valuable spaoe, ask your assistance in drawing attention to this matter, with a view to the establishment ot some satisfactory standard of tonnage.”

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LTD.
div.p: A notice will be found in another column of to-day*8 issue of the approaching flotation of tha important new combine, the Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt, Limited. The names of the directors are a guarantee of the soundness ot the enterprise, and there is every prospect that the capital will be largely over-subscribed All the great cotton houses, such as Messrs. Carver Bros.Co., Ltd, Choremi Benachi and Co., J. Planta and Co., C. M. Salvago and Co., C. G. Zervudachi and Co., and the Soci4t4 d’Egrenage de Zagazig, have undertaken not to gin exoept with the combine. All the properties purchased from the above firms have been paid for in shares of the new oompany.

div.head: CAIRO’S NEW BOURSE
div.p: The contract of purchase Of the land on which the Khedivial Bourse buildings are to be erected inCairohss been signed, with theSocidtd Immobilize. The land in question forms part of the Sabet estate, one part of which was bought by the Nungovich Hotels Company. The latter has deoided to enlarge the Savoy Hotel on the Sabet estate side and to open a new street leading from Kasr el Nil-street to Soliman Pasha-avenue. Shops are to be constructed in the new street. The plot sold to the Khedivial Bourse is situated on the border of Kasr-el Nil-street, where the frontage will be. The cost of purchase and construction will be covered by an issue of shares.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL AND BRITISH SHIPPING.
div.p: Sir H. Vincent asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer in the House of Commons this day week if his attention had been called to the declaration on May 22 ot a dividend for the past year by the Suez Canal Company, which would give the British Government a dividend j for the past year of nearly 28 per cent;, free of taxes, on the investment of4,000,000 in 1875 ; and if he would consider the desirability ot refunding to British toonage passing through the Canal last year some proportion, say, 5’Oih 10pe( \',nt, of the dividend, having regard to the charges it had to meet to earn such an incoiriefor the oompany. The Chancellor of the Exchequer : According to the s^onncement in the publio Press a substantial reduotion in the shipping dues will be proposed at the annual meeting of the oompany. I should not be justified in proposing a grant in aid of a particular seotion of British shipping on the ground stated in the question. Sir H. Vincent said he would call .attention to tbe 8»bj*ot on the ewlint poMibl* ooouion.

div.head: THE GHIRGAH SCANDAL.
HEARING OF WITNESSES.
div.p: Assiout, Son day. To-day began the^ hearing of the famous Ghirgeh case. The lawyers oame from Cairo on Saturday morning together with Aly Bey Abou el Foutonh, Substitut du Piquet The sitting was opened at 8 o’clock this morning under the presidency of Mohamad Bey Saleh, assisted by Hassan Bey Husny and Abdul Aziz Bey Mohamed, the clerk being Abdul Hamid Eff. Hamdi. The attendance in Court was very large, many having oomespe. cially from Cairo, the Fayoum, and Sohag, where the Moudir is v. ell-known. The president announced the opening of the sitting, after which the names of the were called out and they were given chairs to sit on during the trial. The names of the wit-were then called out and these were accommodated in a special room. There were eleven witnesses for the proeeoution and twelve for the defence. After the usual interrogatories of the aooos-ed the Substitut called for the application of Article 180 of the Penal Code against them. The aoonsed were then asked as to whether they were guilty or not guilty of the charge, and it is ioportant to give here the answers of each. The Cadi Shari and the two witnesses of the tawkil, as well as Kamel flft>Waesif(the wekil of the daireh), asserted that the tawkil was genuine. Mohamed Bey Rifi’a deposed that he was in Cairo and therefore could not tell whether his father had signed the tawkil or not, but he thought he must have signed it as he had intended doing so^ The Moudir asserted that he knew nothing about it, that he was not present, and so could not tell whether it was genuine or a forgery. The clerk then read out the charge^heet, aftes which the witnesses were heard. The most important witnesses were Badawy Bey Rifa’at, Sheikh Ahmed Mansour (the clerk who wrote out the tawkil), and Mohamed Eff. Farghali, son-in-law of Badawy Bey. All ed, of course, that the tawkil was forged but it is very important to note one or two points in the testimony of Badawy Bey. The Moudir is aconsed of having ordered Badawy £ey to sign the-tawkil, telling him that it was a register of the Moudirieh oonoeming the property^ the daira. Badawy Bey, iil his evidence, asserted that the Moudir had not ordered him to sign, nor did he say anything, but was merely present K»m*il who had asked him to sign. The clerk of the Mehkemeh asserted also that “a gentleman” (he did not know whether it was the Moudir or some one else) had asked Badawy Bey to sign. But Moh. Eff. Farghali stated that Badawy told him that he signed through the influenoe of the Moudir. The hearing continued at 9 o’olook in the evening. To-morrow the rest of the witnesses will be heard and the pleadings will take plaoe on Tuesday. (By Telegraph). Assiout, Monday afternoon. The Court today heard the evidence of the Commandant of Polioe, who was present with the Moudir in the house of BaaawiBey. He declared that the Moadir was not oonoerned in the matter either bv his verhal orders or by the exertion of his innaenoe.
Assiout, Tuesday morning. To-day the speeches of the counsel for the defence were heard.

div.head: BIOHMO BRIGANDAGE CASE.
div.p: ( From our ^Correspondent ). Fayoum, Sunday. The moudirieh oonncil has sentenced tbe omdeh ofBiohmo to three months’imprisonment for his conduct in the recent brigandage case. Many people consider the sentence a harsh one, as during the 15 years he has acted as omdeh there have been no previous complaints as to the way in which he has carried out his duties, and he has, in fact, been officially commended for the way in which he has performed them. No doubt his oondnct was cowardly on the ocoasion of the attaok on Soliman Said’s house, but the experience was a trying one for him. He has been unaccustomed to use firearms, and the suddenness of the outrage caused him to lose his presence of mind. Perhaps the oounoil thought that by making an example of him they would warn other omdebs of the necessity of being prepared to act in cases of emergenoy. These brigands, instead of being imprisoned, should be sent away out of the oountry to the Su^an. They belong to an organised body who furnish the means for their defenoe, ard provide for the families of any who get caught and imprisoned. The State has to pay for their maintenance in prison, and no good whatever is effected by sending them tbere. Let them be sent right away instead.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Thc .S.S. “Roman Prince,” from Antwerp, left ^ondon on Sunday last, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head: NOTES FROM LUXOR. DEATH FROM SUNSTROKE
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Luxor, Satutifey. The heat here is unbmmbim Resident of Luxor have not known it to ha so hot for many years, and tha hot winds to continue for such a long spell Yesterday an Italian was found dead on the Bayadeah Canal, some kilomeSmi from here. He had arrived from Cairo thssadays ago, and being in straitened circumstances, it appease that he was attempting to walk to Assouan. He did not go £ar, however, before the sun strook Mm and laidhn low. A gentleman, who knew him here, says he leaves a wife and five ohUdran, and used to be formerly in easy circumstances. Soundings are being taken at fiuufc in the Nile, so no doubt the building of the Baoege there will oommenoe next year

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: A matoh, Alexandria versus Aamleh, will be played on the A.O.G» ground on Saturday next at 1.80 p.m.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: A reoaption was held at the Italian Consulate on Sunday morning by Mar^ain 3elv^$*gpit * Italian Diplomatic Agent,.00 the, oooasioaof the celebration of the £astlv4 oi the “Statute.” EI Kaimakam A. Sutherland Bey, o$oer commanding, 15th Sudanese bee bent granted the local rank of Miralai, whilst holding the acting appointment of officer commanding District and Governor jSahfrel-Ghnssli Ibrahim Halim Bey, Governor of Sues, has been granted one month’s leave from the 17th inst. England on Jufy 1, and wiU ba absent for 31/2 months. Two mouths’ leave of absence has been accorded to Alexandre Dimitri Bey, sqlvdireptor ot the Personnel and Aootfunts Department. Mr. H. W. Tite, chief inspector of tbe International. Sleeping Gar Co., returned to Cairo from Cyprus on Sunday and w3l leave for Paris on Saturday next. Mrs. Tite, who has remained in Cyprus, will spend the summer there.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
